data.title: This Guy's in Love With You
data.meta_description: A bet is riding on this!  Who sold more copies of the single "This Guy's/Girl's in Love With You"?  Herb Alpert...or Dionne Warwick?  I say Herb Alpert.  An...
data.text:
Herb Alpert...wasn't the song #1 for a period of time back in July, 1968? I seem to recall that this was the only #1 song the TJB had, and it was an interesting point that it was a vocal from a instrumental group. I seem to recall something like that.

While we're on the topic, did you know that Herb also recorded this song in Spanish and Italian? Yo Soy Ese Amor (b/w Love So Fine - A&M 960), the Spanish version appeared as a U.S. single. The English version appeared on the Mexican album, Herb Alpert Gold Series (A&M / PolyGram LPR 73041 - 39 6948 1), with the more literal title, Este Chico Enamorado De Ti. And the Italian version, Un Ragazzo Che Ti Ama (b/w Hello, Dolly), appeared as A&M Italy single 825, with a date of 8/22/68.

Other stats:

Dionne's version was on the top 40 for 11 weeks beginning 2/8/69.

Herb's version was #1 for 4 weeks, and was in the top 40 for 12 weeks starting 5/25/68.

Interesting factoid: "Rise" was actually in the top 40 longer than "This Guy" (15 weeks as opposed to 12) but was only #1 for two weeks.

And on a font level: Mr. Alpert's "TGILWY" recording, when released as A&M single #929, was the first pressing from Columbia's Pitman, NJ plant to use Pitman's gallery of Linotype fonts for the label copy, since Chris Montez' "There Will Never Be Another You" (#810). In the two-year interregnum, Columbia East Coast pressings of A&M releases used West Coast typefaces (from Santa Maria, CA) entirely; from here until late 1969, they would alternate. Sometimes on the same release ("Black Pearl" by Sonny Charles, #1053, as an example). After that, each of Columbia's plants used their own fonts for A&M releases.

Oh, and did I mention I've always been partial to Herb's version?

What was the song that Herb Alpert's "This Guy's In Love With You" edged-out from making the top-of-the-charts? Richard Harris' "MacArthur Park" or Mason Williams' "Classical Gas"...?

Funny how just when I was hearing Herb's new songs that were instrumentals, that I caught one of his "oldies" and the first time I heard him singing; of course what made it recognizable was his trumpet solo...

Dave

...and wondering if "TG'sILWY" was #1, then what was #2...?
